tossups.question: Traustein stones sometimes named for these objects were built into the northern wall of early German synagogues for a ceremony meant to dispel evil spirits. During Shavuot, the bimah of a synagogue is often decorated with flowers and other greenery to resemble these objects, referencing Moses' role as Israel's "matchmaker." These objects' four doorways embody the act of hachnasat orchim, or hospitality, first exemplified by Abraham. In the final part of a ceremony named for these objects, participants go to break their fast in a secluded yichud room for ten minutes. In that ceremony, participants standing under one of these objects drink wine after seven blessings are recited and crush a glass with their right foot. For 10 points, name these objects which Jewish wedding ceremonies are held under.
tossups.formatted_answer: chuppahs [or wedding canopies]
tossups.answer: chuppahs [or wedding canopies]

tossups.question: A line from this novel beginning "the world is what it is" titles Patrick French's biography of its author. After being defrauded out of a Canadian oil well, a character in this novel opens an ethnic movie theater. This novel's protagonist comes across a badly-printed pamphlet titled "The Shriek of the Ancestors" and joins the Hellenic Club. Upon returning to a country during a period of "radicalization," this novel's protagonist finds that his business has been seized, as has Mahesh's Big Burger franchise. The Belgian Father Huismans dies at the end of this novel's first section. This novel ends with the protagonist taking Ferdinand's advice to leave on a steamboat before the arrival of a dictator called the Big Man. For 10 points, name this novel about the shopkeeper Salim's experiences in an unnamed African country, by V. S. Naipaul.
tossups.formatted_answer: A Bend in the River
tossups.answer: A Bend in the River

tossups.question: The Competency Commission was established to determine fee patents based on the results of this legislation, whose handling was challenged in Cobell v. Salazar. Some people paid five dollar bribes to be included on the "Final Rolls" produced to enforce this legislation, which was criticized in Angie Debo's And the Waters Still Run. John Collier reduced the authority of this legislation by implementing the Wheeler-Howard Act. The Burke Act amended this legislation by limiting access to American citizenship. Helen Hunt Jackson's A Century of Dishonor inspired the creation of this legislation. This legislation, which was also amended by the Curtis Act, established a blood quantum and afforded "mixed-blood" individuals larger tracts of land. For 10 points, name this 1887 act that divided Native American tribal holdings into households.
tossups.formatted_answer: Dawes Act of 1887 [or General Allotment Act; or Dawes Severalty Act of 1887; prompt on Burke Act or Curtis Act until "Burke" is read]
tossups.answer: Dawes Act of 1887 [or General Allotment Act; or Dawes Severalty Act of 1887; prompt on Burke Act or Curtis Act until "Burke" is read]

tossups.question: A function of this quantity is integrated on the left side of an integral formulation by Andrew Naganoff. This quantity is subscripted "d" in a common form of the Cambridge equation. This quantity's growth is the subject of the "k-percent rule." This quantity equals price level times the real value of transactions divided by the "velocity" of transactions, by the equation of exchange. This quantity can be increased by accounting for float. The "zero maturity" type of this quantity does not include time deposits, unlike its M2 type. The central bank can change this quantity in an open market operation by buying or selling bonds. Milton Friedman advocated for this quantity's steady growth in order to control inflation in his theory of monetarism. For 10 points, name this total amount of currency in circulation in an economy.
tossups.formatted_answer: money supply [or money stock or monetary supply or monetary base; accept money zero maturity or MZM before read; accept M0, M1, M2, M3, or MB before M2 is read; prompt on money; prompt on supply; prompt on liquidity; prompt on M]
tossups.answer: money supply [or money stock or monetary supply or monetary base; accept money zero maturity or MZM before read; accept M0, M1, M2, M3, or MB before M2 is read; prompt on money; prompt on supply; prompt on liquidity; prompt on M]

tossups.question: A technique named for this quantity was initially unpopular due to the unimproved power output predicted by Carson's rule. Two similar values of this quantity are difficult to simultaneously detect in the capture effect, which affects a technique named for this quantity invented by Edwin Armstrong. Reginald Fessenden pioneered mixing two values of this quantity, which is called heterodyning. The "selectivity" refers to the ability of a receiver to "select" a value of this quantity. A slight difference between two values of this quantity creates "beats." This quantity has to be much higher for the carrier wave than the signal in radio communications, for which the FCC allocates "bands" of this quantity. For 10 points, amplitude modulation is contrasted with modulation named for what quantity, which is measured in Hertz?
tossups.formatted_answer: frequency [or frequency modulation or carrier frequency or signal frequency or frequency mixing or beat frequency]
tossups.answer: frequency [or frequency modulation or carrier frequency or signal frequency or frequency mixing or beat frequency]

tossups.question: In a play titled for one of these places, the protagonist tries to retrieve a golden gun that belonged to a dictator's son. Kev sees his fellow U.S. soldier Tom lose his hand in a Rajiv Joseph play titled for one of these places in Baghdad. 45 years after writing a play titled for one of these places, its author added the prequel Homelife in a reworking titled for the author At Home at one of these places. In a play titled for one of these places, a man, whose two daughters each have a pet parakeet, hears about a Black drag queen who wears a kimono and a man's attempt to poison his landlady's dog. That man stabs himself at the end of a play titled for one of these places, in which Jerry and Peter end up fighting by a bench in Central Park. For 10 points, an Edward Albee play is titled for a Story about what place?
tossups.formatted_answer: zoos [or The Zoo Story or Edward Albee's At Home at the Zoo or Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo]
tossups.answer: zoos [or The Zoo Story or Edward Albee's At Home at the Zoo or Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo]

tossups.question: J.G. Lorimer was commissioned to create a top-secret "gazetteer" on the geography of this body of water by the British government. Samuel Hennell led peaceful negotiations between several confederations on this body of water to reinforce an 1820 maritime treaty signed with Great Britain. Rahmah, a pirate based in this body of water, assisted the British in an 1819 expedition to challenge Qasimi (kah-SEE-mee) pirates. In the 1950s, a namesake rupee was put into circulation to fight gold traffickers based around this body of water. The largest oil spill in history was orchestrated in this body of water as a scorched earth tactic by forces retreating along Highway 80. Norman Schwarzkopf led coalition forces in that 1990 war named for this body of water. For 10 points, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates lie on what gulf?
tossups.formatted_answer: Persian Gulf [accept Persian after "gulf"]
tossups.answer: Persian Gulf [accept Persian after "gulf"]

tossups.question: The goddess Rán uses a tool for this activity to kill unsuspecting men. That tool for this activity is used to force Andvari to give up the ring Andvaranaut. After he performed this action, a son of Hreidmar and brother of Fafnir is killed by Loki for his pelt. The Gylfaginning recounts a story of this activity where the head of jötunn's best ox was used. While hiding in a house with four doors at Franag's Falls, Loki is caught by Thor with his bare hands after jumping over an object he designed for this activity. Hymir and Thor inadvertently attract the serpent Jourmungandr while doing this activity, which in some versions prompts Hymir to cut the line attached to the serpent. For 10 points, name this activity where Norse seafarers used nets to catch their meals.
tossups.formatted_answer: fishing [accept any answers describing catching fish, but prompt on catching food with "what kind of food?", accept eating fish, but prompt on eating with "what activity was done to gather the food in question?", prompt on answers like sailing or boating with "what activity were they doing at sea?", prompt on swimming with "what activity were they performing that required swimming?"]

tossups.question: Since it was "more advanced," than others in the genre, this composer wrote a No. 7 "Septet" before No. 3, which depicts a woodpecker. Ernesto Nazareth was the dedicatee of this composer's first piece in that genre, which is for solo guitar. A twenty-minute, single-movement piano piece by this composer depicts Arthur Rubinstein and has a title meaning "savage poem." Over the 1920s, this composer wrote 16 pieces in a improvisatory street genre whose name means "weeping." The fifth part of a set of works by this composer of Rudepoema ("ROO-day-poh-AY-mah") and many choros ("HOH-ross") is scored for soprano and eight cellos, while the second depicts a "little train" in the countryside. Those nine suites by this composer, which were influenced by an earlier German Baroque composer, have titles in Portuguese. For 10 points – what composer depicted his homeland in Bachianas brasileiras ("back-ee-AH-nass braz-ill-EHR-ass")?
tossups.formatted_answer: Heitor Villa-Lobos ("HAY-tor vee-ah-LOB-os")
tossups.answer: Heitor Villa-Lobos ("HAY-tor vee-ah-LOB-os")

tossups.question: A "super" form of this compound occurs in the mineral carpathite. The number of moieties that resemble this compound is considered when using Clar's rule. This compound with a significant quadrupole moment was used by Ludwig Roselius (roh-ZAY-lee-uhs) in an early method of decaffeinating coffee. There were several recalls in 2021 as a result of the laboratory Valisure finding trace amounts of this compound in some Neutrogena and Coppertone sunscreen products. One of this compound's hydrogen atoms is replaced by a hydroxyl group in the cumene (KYOO-meen) process. An isomer of this second smallest annulene (ANN-"you-lean") is named for James Dewar (DOO-ur). Sodium in liquid ammonia can be used in the Birch reduction to convert this compound to 1,4-cyclohexadiene. August Kekulé (KEK-yoo-lay) determined the ring structure of, for 10 points, what cyclic hydrocarbon with molecular formula C6H6?
tossups.formatted_answer: benzene [or superbenzene; prompt on C6H6]
tossups.answer: benzene [or superbenzene; prompt on C6H6]

tossups.question: It's not murder, but a third of all people hanged in London between 1800 and 1818 were found guilty of this crime, which was sometimes engaged in by "shovers." In the Roman era, people engaging in this crime might be caught with objects called fourrées (foo-RAYS). Reeded edges are often used to protect against a type of this crime known as clipping. A massive instance of this crime involving "super" objects may have been orchestrated by the North Korean government. George Floyd was killed after being accused of engaging in this crime by Cup Foods. Fighting this crime was the original mission of the U.S. Secret Service. In 2005, the EFF exposed code to guard against this crime in software written by Xerox. For 10 points, name this crime that could involve photocopying greenbacks.
tossups.formatted_answer: counterfeiting [or forgery of bank notes; or answers describing paying with a counterfeit bill; prompt on fraud]
tossups.answer: counterfeiting [or forgery of bank notes; or answers describing paying with a counterfeit bill; prompt on fraud]

tossups.question: In this country, the City of Joy women's community was founded by Christine Schuler Deschryver. In 2021, a gang in this country killed Luca Attanasio, its Italian ambassador, in a region home to the M23 rebels. The Panzi Hospital was founded by a gynecologist from this country who won the 2018 Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts to reduce sexual violence. This country's Lendu and Hema people are engaged in the ongoing Ituri ("it-OO-ri") conflict. This country's public company Gécamines ("GAY-cah-mines") helps exploit the world's largest reserves of coltan and cobalt and competes with négociants using child labor. Under its current president Félix Tshisekedi ("FAY-leeks TSHI-say-kay-dee"), this country is fighting one of its eastern neighbors in the Kivu conflict. Rwanda lies east of, for 10 points, what country formerly led by Joseph Kabila from Kinshasa?
tossups.formatted_answer: Democratic Republic of the Congo [or DR Congo or DRC or DROC or Congo-Kinshasa; prompt on Congo; do not accept or prompt on "Republic of the Congo"]
tossups.answer: Democratic Republic of the Congo [or DR Congo or DRC or DROC or Congo-Kinshasa; prompt on Congo; do not accept or prompt on "Republic of the Congo"]

tossups.question: In a poem by this author, "The Bishop" concludes that "the ways of God are strange!" when "the boys" complain of "some change" due to their various ailments. This poet addressed a German mother who dreams and knits socks for a son whose face is "trodden deeper in the mud." This poet of "They" and "Glory of Women" wrote a "Declaration" whose discovery by Dr. W.H.R. Rivers opens Pat Barker's novel Regeneration. This author's alter ego George Sherston titles a trilogy that opens with Memoirs of a Fox-Hunting Man. A character in a poem by this author falls "down, and down" and "sank and drowned, bleeding to death" following a shout of "O Christ, they're coming at us!" after an officer "blundering down the trench" orders the title "Counter-Attack." For 10 points, name this poet who mentored the younger Wilfred Owen during World War I.
tossups.formatted_answer: Siegfried Sassoon [Siegfried Loraine Sassoon]
tossups.answer: Siegfried Sassoon [Siegfried Loraine Sassoon]

tossups.question: James L. Elliott's observations of this astronomical body led to the 1998 conclusion that it was undergoing global warming. In 2015, NASA proposed a lander that would use this body's surface material as propellant to travel in 5-kilometer long jumps, called this body's "Hopper." This body may have spent over a billion years in a liquid state before reaching its current near-circular orbit, since which it has developed atmospheric features called Hili and Mahilani. Diapirism may have helped form this moon's "cantaloupe terrain," which includes the frozen nitrogen and geysers on its surface, and was observed by Voyager 2 in 1989. This large moon's retrograde orbit suggests that it was captured from the Kuiper (KOI-per) belt. This moon is far greater in size than the nearby moons Proteus and Nereid (NEH-ree-id). For 10 points, name this largest moon of Neptune.
tossups.formatted_answer: Triton
tossups.answer: Triton

tossups.question: Jester Hairston arranged a song of this name for the film Lilies of the Field and dubbed the tone-deaf Sidney Poitier's vocals; the first verse of that call-and-response song of this name opens, "See the little baby wrapped in a manger." This word, with "Brother," titles the B-side to "Color Him Father" by the Winstons, whose seven-second Gregory Coleman drum break is the world's most sampled. This word ends the poem on which the last track of A Love Supreme is based. Because this word is often set to the cadence from IV (four) to I (one), the plagal cadence is also named for it. The loudest church congregants gather in a "corner" of this name. Hymnals often close with settings of this word, a common "threefold" setting of which is named for Dresden. For 10 points, many gospel performers shout what word of affirmation that closes Christian prayers?
tossups.formatted_answer: Amen
tossups.answer: Amen

tossups.question: This theory is supported over the Tangled Bank model by increased recombination frequency in longer-lived species. This theory is also supported by the fact that rare genotypes are less susceptible to common pathogens, leading to fluctuating selection. One experiment that supported this theory noted that obligately selfing populations of C. Elegans are killed by growing them alongside Serratia ("suh-RAY-shuh"). This theory was posited to explain how the probability of a taxon's extinction is independent of its age by Leigh Van Valen. Hamilton used this theory to explain the evolution of sex in response to parasites. An example of this theory is a fox evolving to be faster in order to catch rabbits. For 10 points, name this hypothesis that states that species in an evolutionary arms race must continuously evolve, named for a Lewis Carroll character.
tossups.formatted_answer: Red Queen hypothesis
tossups.answer: Red Queen hypothesis

tossups.question: A type of this activity titles an essay critiquing the conflation of Marx's ideas of commercial and industrial capital, written by Gayatri Spivak. Rousseau (roo-SOW") assigned this activity a "parasitic" role, per an essay that introduced its "arche" ("AR-kay") form. This activity, which is likened to a pharmakon in "Plato's Pharmacy," partly titles a book that features the essays "Violence and Metaphysics" and "Cogito and the History of Madness." This activity, which is paired with "Difference" in the title of that Jacques Derrida book, is the subject of the title science proposed in Derrida's 1967 magnum opus. Those who engage in this activity title an essay after which Derrida's "The Death of Roland Barthes" is titled. For 10 points, Derrida claimed speech was favored over what form of communication with which he created Of Grammatology and other books?
tossups.formatted_answer: writing [or écriture; accept word forms; accept authoring or producing text or scripting or arche-writing or ghostwriting; accept Writing and Difference or L'écriture et la différence] (Spivak's essay attacks Derrida and is titled "Ghostwriting.")

tossups.question: A rubella infection in a pregnant queen from this family precipitated the rise and fall of a faith healer in the Hofmans crisis. This royal house named the countermovement to a post-World War I socialist revolution called the "Red Week." A queen from this royal family quipped about ten-foot-deep water in response to hearing about Kaiser Wilhelm's seven-foot-tall guards. During World War II, Canada gave refuge to this family's infant princess and reigning queen during a disastrous winter famine. The extinction of this house's male lineage in 1890 prompted the end of a personal union with Luxembourg. During the reign of this house's Queen Beatrix, Aruba sought autonomy, and constitutional changes followed in other Caribbean possessions. For 10 points, King Willem-Alexander (VIL-em-ah-lek-ZAHN-dur) belongs to what current royal house of the Netherlands?

tossups.question: The paper-pulp-based print Day and Night is on display in this country's Soumaya Museum. Tina Modotti photographed hundreds of works in this country before joining its Communist Party. An artist from this country painted a Titan reaching for fire in the Frary Dining Hall at Pomona College. A baby's disembodied head appears over scrap metal in the painting Echo of a Scream from this country. Scenes of Ecology and the Atom appear on the outside of a decagon-shaped building in this country called the Polyforum Cultural (polyforum cull-two-rall). A skeleton gives birth to books in a panel created by an artist from this country for the Baker Memorial Library at Dartmouth. Artists from this country painted The March of Humanity and The Epic of American Civilization. For 10 points, name this home country of prominent muralists such as David Siqueiros and José Orozco.
tossups.formatted_answer: Mexico [or United Mexican States; or Estados Unidos Mexicanos]
tossups.answer: Mexico [or United Mexican States; or Estados Unidos Mexicanos]

tossups.question: An author from this country pioneered queer women's literature in a novel about Lidia's coming of age, Dogs and Others. Another author from this country addressed plagiarism accusations in The Anatomy Lesson after copying whole paragraphs from a compatriot's book 7000 Days in Siberia. That author from this country depicted Baruch David Neumann's forced Christian conversion in "Dogs and Books." A story from this country, whose title revolutionary worries about how he will be remembered, is titled for that character's Tomb. A shopkeeper's ear is nailed to stonework in a novel by an author from this former country, the home of Danilo Kiš (KEESH), that depicts 350 years of turbulent history near the title structure, The Bridge on the Drina. For 10 points, name this former Balkan country, home to Ivo Andrić (EE-voh AHN-dritch) and other authors who lived in Belgrade.
tossups.formatted_answer: Yugoslavia [or Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia; or Federal People's Republic of Yugoslavia; accept Serbia; accept Bosnia and Herzegovina; accept Croatia] [The first author is Biljana Jovanović and the unnamed story is "A Tomb for Boris Davidovich."]

bonuses.leadin: Anton Raphael Mengs created a copy of this painting for the Duke of Northumberland, though Mengs titled his copy Philosophy. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Raphael fresco in which Leonardo da Vinci appears as Plato pointing a finger into the air.

Mengs tricked this scholar into believing his fresco Jupiter and Ganymede was from ancient Rome to mock his theories. This German "father of archaeology"'s The History of Art in Antiquity was one of the first examinations of ancient art.

A Mengs painting depicts this woman staring at a cross carved out of a branch. This woman, who sits with a skull in her lap and stares at a candle flickering in a mirror in a Georges de la Tour painting, appears emaciated in a 1453 sculpture made of white poplar.

bonuses.leadin: This term was coined by the sociologist William Petersen in an article about the "success story" of a group that allegedly overcame "self-defeating apathy". For 10 points each:
parts: Name this term. This "stereotype promise" is often studied in conjunction with the "perpetual foreigner" stereotype in analyzing the paradox of overrepresentation and underrepresentation among a certain racial group.

In America, the model minority label is most often applied to members of this general group. Arguments against affirmative action often claim that this immigrant group is disadvantaged by current college quotas.
The application of the model minority label to immigrants from this country was dubbed the "myth of the golden exile".

bonuses.leadin: A play by this author explores the sexual adventures of Florinda, Hellena, and Angellica Bianca during the Naples carnival. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author of The Rover. The protagonist is reunited with Imoinda (im-oh-IN-dah) in this author's novella Oroonoko, often considered the earliest British novel.
Behn's other frank depictions of female sexuality include a prose work titled for some of these texts between "a Nobleman and his Sister." Epistolary novels are comprised of these texts.

Lysander throws himself on the maid Cloris in this Behn poem, originally attributed to the Earl of Rochester. Lysander finds himself in "the Hell of Impotence" after he fails to get an erection in this poem.
answers: love letters [or Love Letters between a Nobleman and his Sister]
formatted_answers: love letters [or Love Letters between a Nobleman and his Sister]

bonuses.leadin: This protein is the namesake of the most common bleeding disease in the United States. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this protein that binds to factor VIII ["eight"], which keeps factor VIII inactive until it's needed for clotting.

von Willebrand factor is stored in the Weibel-Palade bodies of these cells, which line the inner surface of arteries. These cells are also responsible for releasing nitric oxide to cause vasodilation.
Bayer mass-produces this pain reliever, whose anti-platelet properties can prevent heart attacks at low doses. This pain reliever can cause Reye's syndrome in children.

bonuses.leadin: After the coronation of Alfonso IV in the 920s, this kingdom ceased to exist as an independent monarchy and was absorbed into León. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this kingdom, long ruled by Alfonso II, that patronized the theologian Beatus of Liébana (LEE-ah-bah-nah), who wrote against Arianism and adoptionism in favor of Roman Catholic doctrine.
The founder of Asturias, Pelayo, used guerrilla tactics to win this battle around 718 against the Umayyad (oo-MAI-ed) general Alqama (ahl-KAH-mah).
Covadonga became mythologized as the starting point of this campaign against Muslim rule in Iberia, which concluded with the capture of Granada in 1492.

bonuses.leadin: This philosophical position sometimes names the Traditionalist school of Rene Guenon, Ananda Coomaraswamy, Julius Evola, and Frithjof Schuon. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this perspective named by Agostino Steuco, according to which all the world's religions contain a shared set of fundamental truths or universal origin.

Neo-Vedanta inspired a member of this family's study entitled The Perennial Philosophy. "Agnosticism" was coined by a member of this family who debated evolution with Bishop Samuel Wilberforce at an 1860 event at Oxford.

In this discipline, "perennialism" refers to a philosophy focusing on universal truths that have stood the test of time, often done with a Great Books curriculum. John Dewey advocated a contrasting progressive approach in a book titled for Democracy and it.
answers: Huxley [accept Aldous Huxley; accept Thomas Henry Huxley; accept T. H. Huxley]
education [or clear equivalents such as teaching; or learning; or pedagogy' accept Democracy and Education]
formatted_answers: Huxley [accept Aldous Huxley; accept Thomas Henry Huxley; accept T. H. Huxley]
education [or clear equivalents such as teaching; or learning; or pedagogy' accept Democracy and Education]

bonuses.leadin: According to this god's Homeric Hymn, his hunger drove him to run away and eat Apollo's cattle as an infant. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this god of thieves born on Mount Cyllene to the nymph Maia. That same day, this god gifted Apollo with the lyre he had created as compensation for his cattle.

Mount Cyllene is located in this region, whose namesake was also raised by Maia after their mother Callisto was turned into a bear. This region is the home of a shepherd god who created the syrinx flute from the reeds of a nymph he was pursuing.

In a local myth, Mount Cyllene's name comes from the word "crippled," referencing Hermes' dismemberment after stealing this activity invented in Arcadia. The princess Palaestra lends her name to ancient schools for this activity, deriving from her aid to Hermes in that myth.

bonuses.leadin: After they mock her for being seduced by an ex-soldier, Tanya stops visiting the title pretzel bakers in this author's story "Twenty-Six Men and a Girl." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author. A play by this author ends with Satin retorting, "You spoiled the song," after the Baron brings news of the Actor's suicide to a dingy boarding-house basement by the Volga.
Gorky's stories and plays were foundational to the Soviet genre of "realism" that espoused Communist values and was usually named for this political belief.

Long after Gorky published some stories in this author's magazine Chronicle, this author declared that "I owe everything to that meeting." Gorky is the dedicatee of a story by this author about his admission to a Russian gymnasium during a pogrom, "The Story of My Dovecot."

bonuses.leadin: The horizontal component of the normal reaction provides this force for a motorbike rider on a "wall of death." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this inward force that maintains bodies in circular motion, which points in the opposite direction to the fictitious centrifugal force.

In general motion, the centripetal force is always directed towards a point of this name. In optics, any ray passing through a point of this name reflects normally off a spherical mirror and goes back along its initial line.
The centripetal force acting on a particle in flat circular motion has this value as a function of its mass "M," velocity "V" and radius of curvature "R."
answers: center of curvature [or COC; prompt on partial answers]
M V squared over R [or M times V squared divided by R or other equivalents; accept "mass" in place of "M;" accept "velocity" in place of "V;" accept "radius (of curvature)" in place of "R"]
formatted_answers: center of curvature [or COC; prompt on partial answers]

bonuses.leadin: This crop was the main output of the "strange farmer" system of labor in Gambia. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this crop once governed by Senegal's chit system, whose neglect partially instigated the breakup of Senegambia. Under Clement Attlee, the Labour Party launched a failed attempt at cultivating this crop in Tanganyika.

Farmers' limited ability to hire labor led this country's future president, Félix Houphouët-Boigny (fay-LEEKS oo-fet boh-nee), to found the SAA. Houphouët coined the term Françafrique (FRAHN-sah-FREEK) to refer to this country's ties with its former colonizer.

Amilcar Cabral criticized this empire's focus on peanut farming in Guinea-Bissau, whose war of independence is sometimes called this empire's "Vietnam." That war ended in 1974 after this empire's last outposts were divested following the Carnation Revolution.
answers: Portuguese empire [or Portugal; or Second Portuguese Republic; or Segunda República Portuguesa; prompt on Estado Novo]
formatted_answers: Portuguese empire [or Portugal; or Second Portuguese Republic; or Segunda República Portuguesa; prompt on Estado Novo]

bonuses.leadin: Anecdotally, this author went around yelling "I am Arturo Bandini!" in reference to John Fante's literary alter ego. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author, whom Bill Buford identified as the "godfather" of "dirty realism." The alter ego Henry Chinaski was introduced in this author's novel Post Office.
Bukowski set much of his misanthropic fiction in this city, his longtime home. John Fante's Ask the Dust is set in this city, as is F. Scott Fitzgerald's The Last Tycoon.

Detective Nicky Belane tries to find author Louis-Ferdinand Céline in a Bukowski novel titled for this adjective, which describes cheap magazines of lowbrow stories. "The Gold Watch" is part of Roger Avary's screenplay for a Quentin Tarantino film titled for this kind of Fiction.

bonuses.leadin: This piece's 25th variation's "wistful, weary cantilena" ("CAN-tee-LAY-nah") was described as "a master-stroke of psychology" by its frequent performer Glenn Gould ("gool'd"). For 10 points each:
parts: Name this piece, whose opening bars are inscribed on Gould's gravestone. Gould performed this J.S. Bach piece's 32 sections on the 1955 album that brought him to fame.

The darkness of the 25th Goldberg variation is due in good part to its use of a key with this relationship to the opening G major aria. Keys with this relationship share a tonic but have different key signatures.

The oft-quoted description of the 25th Goldberg variation as a "black pearl" was given by this Polish harpsichord virtuoso of the early 20th century. She was the dedicatee of Francis Poulenc's ("POO-lonk's") harpsichord concerto Concert champêtre ("con-SAIR shom-PET-ruh").
answers: Goldberg Variations, BWV 988 [accept either underlined part; or Clavierübung IV]
parallel keys [or parallel relationship; or parallel minor; prompt on tonic minor]
formatted_answers: Goldberg Variations, BWV 988 [accept either underlined part; or Clavierübung IV]
parallel keys [or parallel relationship; or parallel minor; prompt on tonic minor]

bonuses.leadin: Jon Hendricks's lyrics to this song, which begin "five thousand years from" its title place "but I'm still preachin' the rhythm," are featured on The Manhattan Transfer's Grammy-winning cover that opens their album Extensions. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Joe Zawinul standard that opens Weather Report's album Heavy Weather.

After Zawinul's synth introduction, Jaco Pastorius plays the melody on this instrument, whose removed frets allowed for false harmonics. Unlike Charles Mingus, Pastorius favored this electric instrument over its upright acoustic counterpart.

This musician's cover of "Birdland" opens an album whose re-release bills him as The Greatest Drummer That Ever Lived. This drummer battled Max Roach on a 1959 album, and often performed televised battles with Gene Krupa.

bonuses.leadin: An ancient factory for processing this resource was discovered at Buhen in 1962. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this resource which has been mined for millennia in a namesake "belt" partly located in Zambia. This resource sometimes lends its name to the Chalcolithic age.

People in what is now northern Niger (nee-ZHAIR) seem to have discovered copper smelting independently of other civilizations, due to the isolation ensuing from the end of the "wet phase" of this desert.

Work by Aurélie Cuénod (oh-RAY-lee C'WAY-no) in 2015 suggested that this ancient Saharan civilization based in what is now Libya imported copper from elsewhere. Irrigation systems called foggara (foh-GAH-rah) served this civilization, which, like the Mauri (MAH-oo-ree) and Musulamii (moo-soo-LAH-mee), aided the rebel Tacfarinas (tak-FAA-ree-nas) in attacks on Roman coastal settlements.

bonuses.leadin: The Cauchy-Hadamard ("CO-shee-HAD-ah-mar") theorem states that this value is one over the limit, as n tends to infinity, of the nth root of the coefficient "c sub n." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this quantity, which is finite if the limit in the ratio test exists. If expanded around zero, a power series tends to a finite value if the input is within this value of the origin.
If the input is outside the radius of convergence, the power series exhibits this property, in which it does not tend to a finite value. The harmonic series has this property.

Rather than a radius of convergence, these series have an abscissa of convergence. The "ordinary" type of these infinite series are often written as the sum of "a sub n over n to the power s," a special case of which is the Riemann ("REE-man") zeta function.

bonuses.leadin: At this battle, Daniel Morgan's forces executed the only double envelopment of the Revolutionary War. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this South Carolina battle, a decisive American victory fought in a pasture in January 1781 that began the retreat of British control in the South.
This American lieutenant colonel at Cowpens was legendarily saved from death by an unnamed Black soldier, who shot a charging British cornet. He was the cousin of a later President.

That unnamed soldier was one of the people profiled in this author's Black Profiles in Courage, co-written with Alan Steinberg. This author of the 2021 article "Why the Host of 'Jeopardy!' Matters" also co-wrote a series of novels with Anna Waterhouse about Mycroft Holmes.
answers: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar [or Ferdinand Lewis Alcindor, Jr.; or Lew Alcindor]
formatted_answers: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar [or Ferdinand Lewis Alcindor, Jr.; or Lew Alcindor]

bonuses.leadin: Allah swears to the authenticity of these events in Surah An-Najm, the earliest surah that requires prostration during recitation. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify these events, the first of which is commemorated on the Night of Power in the last 10 days of Ramadan. The products of these events are termed "Meccan" or "Medinan" based on whether they occurred before or after the Hijra.
An-Najm is named for these objects on which Allah swears. In surah 12, Yusuf dreams of eleven of these objects bowing to him.

Hadith identify these beings as the devils struck down by shooting stars when they try to steal Allah's divine transmission. Since the Quran says Shaytan was made of smokeless fire, he is sometimes considered one of these beings.
answers: revelations of the Quran [accept obvious equivalents or reasonable descriptions of events in which Muhammad receives the Quran; prompt on revelations]
formatted_answers: revelations of the Quran [accept obvious equivalents or reasonable descriptions of events in which Muhammad receives the Quran; prompt on revelations]

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about Caribbean islands that are divided between two countries, for 10 points each:
parts: The border region of this island has been the site of atrocities like the Parsley Massacre due to immigration over the border between Haiti and the Dominican Republic.

Two men were allegedly sent to walk around this island's shoreline in 1648 in order to divide it between France and the Netherlands. Spectacular photos of low-flying jets are taken on the tourist beach next to this island's Princess Juliana International Airport.

The name of an island in the Barima delta shared between Venezuela and Guyana repeats this four-letter name. A city of this name was the first capital of the Venezuela Province and became the first German colony in the Americas under the name New Augsburg.

bonuses.leadin: Classically, love poetry in this language was divided into five thinais (tin-AYS) associated with one of five landscapes, such that poems about long separation were set at the seashore at sunset. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this language of Sangam literature. Kannagi cuts off her breast and curses a city after false accusations against her husband in Silappatikaram, one of this language's Great Epics.

Among the oldest extant Tamil texts is the Tolkāppiyam, a textbook on this subject of Pāṇini's (PAH-ni-ni's) Ashtadhyayi (osh-TAH-dya-yee). The classical trivium consisted of logic, rhetoric, and this discipline concerned with the structural rules of language.
This creator of a shortened prose translation of the Tamil Ramayana set several of his novels, including Swami and Friends, in a fictional Tamil Nadu town called Malgudi.

bonuses.leadin: For decellularizing organs, biochemists frequently use the ionic detergents SDS or non-ionic Triton X-100 as these substances to separate cells from the extracellular matrix. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these substances, a pulmonary type of which lubricates alveoli. These compounds decrease interfacial tension.

Triton X-100's side chain is this polymer sold as the laxative macrogol. This polymer is attached to hydrophobic pharmaceuticals to increase their solubility, and attached to the lipid nanoparticles which deliver the mRNA in the Moderna and Pfizer COVID vaccines.
One method of producing detergents is this reaction, in which a strong base hydrolyzes an ester to an alcohol and a carboxylic acid.

bonuses.leadin: This sculpture's most common title is derived from a line from The Flowers of Evil inscribed on its base. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this sculpture of a man carrying a woman in his arms, created by combining the previously unrelated sculptures Falling Man and Crouching Woman. It appears on the righthand pilaster of a larger sculpture.
Those sculptures are part of this French artist's The Gates of Hell, which also contains a statue of Dante called The Thinker.

Rodin sculpted this author in "the Robe of a Dominican Monk" as a study for a minimalist Monument to this author, which Kenneth Clark called the greatest piece of sculpture since Michelangelo, but contemporary critics despised.
answers: I am beautiful [or Je suis belle; or The Abduction; or Carnal Love; or The Cat]
Honoré de Balzac [accept Balzac in the Robe of a Dominican Monk; accept Monument to Balzac]
formatted_answers: I am beautiful [or Je suis belle; or The Abduction; or Carnal Love; or The Cat]
Honoré de Balzac [accept Balzac in the Robe of a Dominican Monk; accept Monument to Balzac]
